utterances: Right.
And I think that - and this is true - and in fact with the Broncos, not just the best offense, it's the best all-time offense - 606 points in the regular season.
And that alone convinces some people that what's happened so far is past is prologue and is going to predict the game.
But I, you know, in the week leading up to the game there's so much talk, and so much of it is statistically based.
But I just always come back to the fact that in the sport of football there are only 16 games.
It's an extremely small sample size.
So, I'm not saying that Denver doesn't have a great offense.
I'm not saying that Seattle doesn't have a defense that held opponents to 14 points.
But, you know, when you talk about baseball, that's 160 games; when you talk about basketball, it's 81 games, plus they play, you know, almost 20 games before they get to the Finals.
I just don't think that statistical set that we see is that indicative.
And then add to the fact, you know, the Broncos and Seahawks have both played 18 games but only against 13 different opponents.
And the Broncos played against the second-easiest set of defenses and the Seahawks played against second-easiest set of offenses.
So...
So, you're saying this is a myth, that the Broncos don't have the best offense and the Seahawks don't have the...
I think they absolutely do but I don't know that you can say, hey, 37.5 points in the regular season.
That's all you need to know.
That's far from all you need to know.
What about the whole Peyton Manning claim?
I mean, the greatest quarterback ever, right?
I think that's, again, based on the statistic of going into this game he's 11-11 in the playoffs.
Now, I get that, and I get the fact that he could be called the greatest player ever if he loses.
But, you know, there is something too.
There's been a backlash.
There had been so many people writing that how could you even question Peyton Manning's legacy.
Win or lose, he's one of the greatest.
Yeah, but win, he is the greatest.
It's the funny thing about legacies.
I mean, two Super Bowl wins are an amazing accomplishment.
If John Updike had won one Pulitzer Prize instead of two Pulitzer Prizes, that would be less notable.
And it's weird - I was thinking about actors and directors and Pulitzer Prizes - the work was already done.
So, in the case of, you know, an artist it's just someone looking at it and saying, oh yeah, you deserve a prize.
But with Manning, this is his work.
So, if the working isn't as good, it's like saying, well, if John Updike didn't write ""Rabbit, Run,"" would his legacy be a little worse?
I think it would be a little worse.
I think that's fair.
(LAUGHTER)
You're not going to tell me who you think's going to win real quick...
Yes, I pick Updike.
Oh, no. I think it might be the Seahawks but I don't know.
Really?
Yeah, just because I think everyone's gone crazy for the Broncos.
And they're great, but yeah.
All right.
Curveball.
What you got?
Well, speaking of the Seahawks, one of my favorite Seahawks to talk to this week was their place-kicker, Steven Hauschka.
He had to decide between dental school and playing in the NFL.
He chose the NFL, yes.
But I brought him a test.
I brought to his attention a chart of the teeth and asked him to name that tooth.
Here's some of that.
What is tooth number eight?
Oh my - oh, my mom's not going to be happy about this.
Now, his mom is a dentist.
His brother is a dentist.
I thought I'd give him another chance to name that tooth.
I should know that.
Give me another one.
All right - 32.
I think you could maybe get 32.
A molar.
It just seemed like such an untapped territory.
To have a show like this, especially now.
And it's been like that since Dave Chappelle when off in 2004, this is 2008, it's been almost four years now.
There's so much happening in our society, and we're just not hearing from that point of view.
You attended the Yale School of Drama.
Yes I did.
And you were performing Shakespeare and Mollier.
It seems that, clear, that what you're doing is your voice.
So how did you go from doing, you know, the greats, but not, obviously, you own material, to evolving into someone who can write as well as perform?
It was a long journey.
I mean, because, you know, after ""In Living Color,"" the last thing I wanted to do was another sketch show.
And at that time, I wanted to do my great sitcom, you know, Davy's World, David's Head, whatever it was going to be.
That didn't happen.
I never really found my comfort zone, my artistic voice, in that arena.
And I think a lot of it had to do with how I am perceived by others in the industry.
You know, I grew up in Detroit, Michigan.
Yeah, I went to Yale.
I did ""In Living Color,"" which is probably the most popular thing people know me from.
But I also did Shakespeare In The Park.
My interests and my psyche are multifaceted.
And usually people pick one or two aspects and say, oh, this is who you are.
So that, I really think, has been part of the problem.

That after years of working with other people, and trying and helping, to varying degrees, help their artistic vision come about, it really was - I just want to do this one show that I've been waiting to do, and this time I won't take a bad job, I'm going to see it all the way through.
So what do you watch in the real news world?
Or listen to?
Because, obviously, a show like yours, you have to pay attention to things.
I'll tell you what.
Usually, every morning I get up very early.
Five thirty-ish, I go online, and I start reading.
And it's always the New York Times, USA Today.
So I start high, and then just slide low.
What's your smell test for whether or not something can be made funny?
If the idea grows.
So meaning, if we start talking, my first question to myself, and my fellow writers, when we start conversing about something we want to do, why is the ""Chocolate News"" doing this story?
If they can't answer it, that's really the end of the discussion.
It doesn't matter how funny it is, and we've killed really funny, hilarious, ideas.
And we have a lot of freedom to justify why we do it.
Because it's our show.
It's my show.
All I have to say is - but there has to be an in.
meaning, you have to set up some kind of false importance.
Which means, you know, I'll give you an absurd example.
We're talking about doing a news story, we made this whole thing up that for a long time the electric chair, where prisoners were electrocuted in America, were segregated.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And we profile the first black man who really broke that color line.
Because it used to be the electric chairs that they electrocuted African-American prisoner in were so brutal that he lobbied and fought to be killed in the white mans electric chair.
So that's a really dark, and I think really funny, biting way to talk about that whole issue.
Now, I have a request...
Uh oh.
and obviously, you don't have to do it because I can't force you.
Is it going to be weird?
It is very weird.
OK.
Jeremiah Wright.
Yes?
One of the biggest figures of this election brouhaha.
Can you give me a couple of sentences as Jeremiah?
Yeah, well first of all, let me just comment that he really isn't that big.
That he made a statement, and right now, people are really talking about it.
But yeah, yeah, I'll do it.
Not to digress.
So what would Jeremiah Wright say?
(As Jeremiah Wright) This white government has invented a form of booty cancer that is killing the black man.
See that is something that...
I love it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I love it.
It would be if Jeremiah Wright got a medical show.
Yeah, yeah, yes, yes.
That would be...
Why - yeah, why are black people dying of athlete's foot?
Clearly it's a plot by the racist white government.
That would be one of his arguments that he did.
One last thing, before we let you go.
You have this sketch on your first show about the N word.
And that's what we call it on NPR, is the N word.
